formattedAddress: 120 Christopher St, New York, NY 10014, USA
adrFormatAddress: 120 Christopher St, New York, NY 10014, USA

editorialSummary.text: French techniques meet Chinese & Himalayan flavors at this refined eatery inside a minimalist space.

originalText.text:
The oyster and the everything brioche were delicious, and the rest was up to the standard, although it's not enough to get you full.

What was a bit off was the level of service:
Food  put aggressively on the table, lack of politeness and of articulation from the waiters when presenting the servings. Coming from abroad, and despite his poor level of service, I got worried that my waiter did not receive a tip. He abruptly redirected me to one colleague I assume to be the manager "hey, talk to him!" and left. The manager kindly explained to me the system of "delayed payment" and that the waiter would receive his tip once they close the shift. Which at that point I was almost starting to regret...

The seats, made of wood, were uncomfortable and there was a lot of proximity with the other tables.

I've visited several restaurants in the Michelin : this one deserves to be in there as a recommendation for the food, but because of everything else I don't think it deserves a star...

originalText.text:
My first time ever returning a dish.
My wife and I came here for restaurant week lunch. We ordered pork bun, and Szechuan karaage. Main dish: Hainan chicken and beef noodle soup.
Szechuan Karaage (4 Star) is the only good dish.
Pork bun(0.5 Star) : the bun is NOT fresh steamed more like microwaved over night, dry and not fluffy. Pork belly is super dry and the fat is not rendered enough.
Hainan chicken (1.5 star) likes fast food style. Fatty chicken skin dry rice.
Beef noodle soup(0 Star): soup is so oily, you can see a layer of fat froze on the surface. the soup tastes so salty and tons of msg. I only sipped a bit and I exchanged for pasta(3star).
The restaurant dish is way different from their normal dish. But come on, you got to set some standards. 2 course for $45 still same price as your dinner course.
And automatic 20% service fee is added. The waitress only served water and take order. After I returned dish, there is no communication about why the dish is so salty.
Very disappointed.

originalText.text: I had no expectations when I came here.. It was only after I saw that they had a michelin star... Honestly the food was just ok for the price.. I had the tasting menu and some items were quite nice (agnolotti) , whereas others fell a bit short (lobster 3 way). I think if it's just a regular restaurant, it was fine.. But then for a michelin star one, then it's quite lacking. Service was pretty good, although they were not busy at all..

originalText.text:
Great restaurant, would recommend. Awesome price to quality ratio.

Went with my wife on a Saturday night for dinner. We sat at the bar and had the tasting menu plus some cocktails.

Food was delicious, particularly the lobster fried rice (within the "lobster three ways"), the oysters and the dessert (the ice cream was superior). Great combination of flavors and textures. You can really see that, even though is "modern American" food, the identity of the chef is impregned into the dishes.
We also tried the hamburger and the chicken sandwich as we stayed several hours talking with Marcos. Both dishes were really good (particularly the hamburger).
Cocktails are a strong element of this restaurant, there is a lot of thought and efforts put into them. Nothing to envy to some of the best bars in NYC.

I would say this place has a great value preposition which perhaps is not being exploited; given the quality of the cocktails, the great price to quality ratio of the food and the nature of the dishes, it's a great spot for a superior night out without going through the hassle of "fine dining".

originalText.text:
Interesting food with some Asian influence. We got the prix fixe. I enjoyed the creative dishes but I think they could've pushed the flavors a bit more. For example the salt and pepper lobster in the lobster 3 ways dish was interesting but could've had a slightly more intense flavor like the salt and pepper street food in Taiwan. I loved the pasta dishes and the everything brioche.

While I loved the plateware and the general vibe was not bad, I do think the place was very loud and it was difficult to hear my boyfriend even though we were at a small table.
